sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Here is Socrates; shall we take him as a partner in our discussion?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: If you like.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Cratylus, whom you see here, Socrates, says that everything has a right name of its own, which comes by nature, and that a name is not whatever people call a thing by agreement, just a piece of their own voice applied to the thing, but that there is a kind of inherent correctness in names, which is the same for all men, both Greeks and barbarians. So I ask him whether his name is in truth Cratylus, and he agrees that it is. “And what is Socrates' name?” I said. “Socrates,” said he. “Then that applies to all men, and the particular name by which we call each person is his name?” And he said, “Well, your name is not Hermogenes,i.e. you are no son of Hermes. Hermes was the patron deity of traders, bankers, and the like, and Hermogenes, as is suggested below, was not successful as a moneymaker. even if all mankind call you so.” Now, though I am asking him and am exerting myself to find out what in the world he means, he does not explain himself at all; he meets me with dissimulation, claiming to have some special knowledge of his own about it which would, if he chose to speak it out clearly, make me agree entirely with him. Now if you could interpret Cratylus's oracular speech, I should like to hear you; or rather, I should like still better to hear, if you please, what you yourself think about the correctness of names.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hermogenes, son of Hipponicus, there is an ancient saying that knowledge of high things is hard to gain; and surely knowledge of names is no small matter. Now if I had attended Prodicus's fifty-drachma course of lectures, after which, as he himself says, a man has a complete education on this subject, there would be nothing to hinder your learning the truth about the correctness of names at once; but I have heard only the one-drachma course, and so I do not know what the truth is about such matters. However, I am ready to join you and Cratylus in looking for it. But as for his saying that Hermogenes is not truly your name, I suspect he is making fun of you; for perhaps he thinks that you want to make money and fail every time. But, as I said, it is difficult to know such things. We must join forces and try to find out whether you are right, or Cratylus.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: For my part, Socrates, I have often talked with Cratylus and many others, and cannot come to the conclusion that there is any correctness of names other than convention and agreement. For it seems to me that whatever name you give to a thing is its right name; and if you give up that name and change it for another, the later name is no less correct than the earlier, just as we change the names of our servants; for I think no name belongs to any particular thing by nature, but only by the habit and custom of those who employ it and who established the usage. But if this is not the case, I am ready to hear and to learn from Cratylus or anyone else.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It may be that you are right, Hermogenes; but let us see. Whatever name we decide to give each particular thing is its name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whether the giver be a private person or a state?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, suppose I give a name to some thing or other, designating, for instance, that which we now call “man” as “horse” and that which we now call “horse” as “man,” will the real name of the same thing be “man” for the public and “horse” for me individually, and in the other case “horse” for the public and “man” for me individually? Is that your meaning?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, that is my opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now answer this question. Is there anything which you call speaking the truth and speaking falsehood?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then there would be true speech and false speech?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then that speech which says things as they are is true, and that which says them as they are not is false?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is possible, then, to say in speech that which is and that which is not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But is true speech true only as a whole, and are its parts untrue?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, its parts also are true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are the large parts true, but not the small ones, or are all true?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: All, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is there, then, anything which you say is a smaller part of speech than a name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, that is the smallest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the name is spoken as a part of the true speech?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is, according to you, true.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And a part of false speech is false, is it not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is possible to utter either a false or a true name, since one may utter speech that is either true or false?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then whatever each particular person says is the name of anything, that is its name for that person?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And whatever the number of names anyone says a thing has, it will really have that number at the time when he says it?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, Socrates, for I cannot conceive of any other kind of correctness in names than this; I may call a thing by one name, which I gave, and you by another, which you gave. And in the same way, I see that states have their own different names for the same things, and Greeks differ from other Greeks and from barbarians in their use of names.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now, Hermogenes, let us see. Do you think this is true of the real things, that their reality is a separate one for each person, as Protagoras said with his doctrine that man is the measure of all things—that things are to me such as they seem to me, and to you such as they seem to you—or do you think things have some fixed reality of their own?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: It has sometimes happened to me, Socrates, to be so perplexed that I have been carried away even into this doctrine of Protagoras; but I do not at all believe he is right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, have you ever been carried away so far as not to believe at all that any man is bad?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Lord, no; but I have often been carried away into the belief that certain men, and a good many of them, are very bad.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, did you never think any were very good?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Very few.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you did think them so?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what is your idea about that? Are the very good very wise and the very bad very foolish?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, that is my opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now if Protagoras is right and the truth is as he says, that all things are to each person as they seem to him, is it possible for some of us to be wise and some foolish?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, it is not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you are, I imagine, strongly of the opinion that if wisdom and folly exist, it is quite impossible that Protagoras is right, for one man would not in reality be at all wiser than another if whatever seems to each person is really true to him.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But neither do you believe with Euthydemus that all things belong equally to all men at the same time and perpetually,The doctrine here attributed to Euthydemus is not expressly enunciated by him in the dialogue which bears his name, but it is little more than a comprehensive statement of the several doctrines there proclaimed by him and his brother Dionysodorus. for on this assumption also some could not be good and others bad, if virtue and its opposite were always equally possessed by all.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if neither all things belong equally to all men at the same time and perpetually nor each thing to each man individually, it is clear that things have some fixed reality of their own, not in relation to us nor caused by us; they do not vary, swaying one way and another in accordance with our fancy, but exist of themselves in relation to their own reality imposed by nature.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think, Socrates, that is the case.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Can things themselves, then, possess such a nature as this, and that of their actions be different? Or are not actions also a class of realities?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly they are.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then actions also are performed according to their own nature, not according to our opinion. For instance, if we undertake to cut anything, ought we to cut it as we wish, and with whatever instrument we wish, or shall we, if we are willing to cut each thing in accordance with the nature of cutting and being cut, and with the natural instrument, succeed in cutting it, and do it rightly, whereas if we try to do it contrary to nature we shall fail and accomplish nothing?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think the way is as you suggest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, too, if we undertake to burn anything, we must burn not according to every opinion, but according to the right one? And that is as each thing naturally burns or is burned and with the natural instrument?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And all other actions are to be performed In like manner?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And speaking is an action, is it not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if a man speaks as he fancies he ought to speak, will he speak rightly, or will he succeed in speaking if he speaks in the way and with the instrument in which and with which it is natural for us to speak and for things to be spoken, whereas otherwise he will fail and accomplish nothing?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think the way you suggest is the right one.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now naming is a part of speaking, for in naming I suppose people utter speech.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then is not naming also a kind of action, if speaking is a kind of action concerned with things?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But we saw that actions are not merely relative to us, but possess a separate nature of their own?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then in naming also, if we are to be consistent with our previous conclusions, we cannot follow our own will, but the way and the instrument which the nature of things prescribes must be employed, must they not? And if we pursue this course we shall be successful in our naming, but otherwise we shall fail.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think you are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again, what has to be cut, we said, has to be cut with something.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what has to be woven, has to be woven with something, and what has to be bored, has to be bored with something?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And then what has to be named, has to be named with something?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what is that with which we have to bore?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: A borer.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that with which we weave?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: A shuttle.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that with which we must name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: A name.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Right. A name also, then, is a kind of instrument.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if I were to ask “What instrument is the shuttle?” Is it not that with which we weave?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what do we do when we weave? Do we not separate the mingled threads of warp and woof?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you could give a similar answer about the borer and the rest, could you not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can you say something of the same kind about a name? The name being an instrument, what do we do with it when we name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do we not teach one another something, and separate things according to their natures?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A name is, then, an instrument of teaching and of separating reality, as a shuttle is an instrument of separating the web?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But the shuttle is an instrument of weaving?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The weaver, then, will use the shuttle well, and well means like a weaver; and a teacher will use a name well, and well means like a teacher.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whose work will the weaver use well when he uses the shuttle?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: The carpenter's.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is every one a carpenter, or he who has the skill?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: He who has the skill.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And whose work will the hole-maker use when he uses the borer?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: The smith's.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is every one a smith, or he who has the skill?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: He who has the skill.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And whose work will the teacher use when he uses the name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I cannot tell that, either.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can you not tell this, either, who gives us the names we use?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you not think it is the law that gives them to us?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the teacher, when he uses a name, will be using the work of a lawgiver?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you think every man is a lawgiver, or only he who has the skill?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: He who has the skill.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is not for every man, Hermogenes, to give names, but for him who may be called the name-maker; and he, it appears, is the lawgiver, who is of all the artisans among men the rarest.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: See now what the lawgiver has in view in giving names. Look at it in the light of what has gone before. What has the carpenter in view when he makes a shuttle? Is it not something the nature of which is to weave?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, if the shuttle breaks while he making it, will he make another with his mind fixed on that which is broken, or on that form with reference to which he was making the one which he broke?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: On that form, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we should very properly call that the absolute or real shuttle?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then whenever he has to make a shuttle for a light or a thick garment, or for one of linen or of wool or of any kind whatsoever, all of them must contain the form or ideal of shuttle, and in each of his products he must embody the nature which is naturally best for each?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the same applies to all other instruments. The artisan must discover the instrument naturally fitted for each purpose and must embody that in the material of which he makes the instrument, not in accordance with his own will, but in accordance with its nature. He must, it appears, know how to embody in the iron the borer fitted by nature for each special use.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And he must embody in the wood the shuttle fitted by nature for each kind of weaving.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For each kind of shuttle is, it appears, fitted by nature for its particular kind of weaving, and the like is true of other instruments.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, my dear friend, must not the law-giver also know how to embody in the sounds and syllables that name which is fitted by nature for each object? Must he not make and give all his names with his eye fixed upon the absolute or ideal name, if he is to be an authoritative giver of names? And if different lawgivers do not embody it in the same syllables, we must not forget this ideal name on that account; for different smiths do not embody the form in the same iron, though making the same instrument for the same purpose, but so long as they reproduce the same ideal, though it be in different iron, still the instrument is as it should be, whether it be made here or in foreign lands, is it not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: On this basis, then, you will judge the law-giver, whether he be here or in a foreign land, so long as he gives to each thing the proper form of the name, in whatsoever syllables, to be no worse lawgiver, whether here or anywhere else, will you not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now who is likely to know whether the proper form of shuttle is embodied in any piece of wood? The carpenter who made it, or the weaver who is to use it ?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Probably the one who is to use it, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then who is to use the work of the lyre-maker? Is not he the man who would know best how to superintend the making of the lyre and would also know whether it is well made or not when it is finished?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: The lyre-player.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And who would know best about the work of the ship-builder?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: The navigator.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And who can best superintend the work of the lawgiver and judge of it when it is finished, both here and in foreign countries? The user, is it not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not this he who knows how to ask questions?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the same one knows also how to make replies?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the man who knows how to ask and answer questions you call a dialectician?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, that is what I call him.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The work of the carpenter, then, is to make a rudder under the supervision of the steersman, if he rudder is to be a good one.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the work of the lawgiver, as it seems, is to make a name, with the dialectician as his supervisor, if names are to be well given.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, Hermogenes, the giving of names can hardly be, as you imagine, a trifling matter, or a task for trifling or casual persons: and Cratylus is right in saying that names belong to things by nature and that not every one is an artisan of names, but only he who keeps in view the name which belongs by nature to each particular thing and is able to embody its form in the letters and syllables.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I do not know how to answer you, Socrates; nevertheless it is not easy to change my conviction suddenly. I think you would be more likely to convince me, if you were to show me just what it is that you say is the natural correctness of names.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I, my dear Hermogenes, do not say that there is any. You forget what I said a while ago, that I did not know, but would join you in looking for the truth. And now, as we are looking, you and I, we already see one thing we did not know before, that names do possess a certain natural correctness, and that not every man knows how to give a name well to anything whatsoever. Is not that true?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then our next task is to try to find out, if you care to know about it, what kind of correctness that is which belongs to names.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: To be sure I care to know.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then investigate.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How shall I investigate?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The best way to investigate, my friend, is with the help of those who know; and you make sure of their favour by paying them money. They are the sophists, from whom your brother Callias got his reputation for wisdom by paying them a good deal of money. But since you have not the control of your inheritance, you ought to beg and beseech your brother to teach you the correctness which he learned of Protagoras about such matters.

Hermogenes It would be an absurd request for me, Socrates, if I, who reject the TruthTruth was the title of a book written by Protagoras. of Protagoras altogether, should desire what is said in such a Truth, as if it were of any value.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if you do not like that, you ought to learn from Homer and the other poets.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Why, Socrates, what does Homer say about names, and where?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In many passages; but chiefly and most admirably in those in which he distinguishes between the names by which gods and men call the same things. Do you not think he gives in those passages great and wonderful information about the correctness of names? For clearly the gods call things by the names that are naturally right. Do you not think so?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Of course I know that if they call things, they call them rightly. But what are these instances to which you refer?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Do you not know that he says about the river in Troy which had the single combat with Hephaestus,Hom. Il. 21.342-380
whom the gods call Xanthus, but men call ScamanderHom. Il. 20.74?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Well, do you not think this is a grand thing to know, that the name of that river is rightly Xanthus, rather than Scamander? Or, if you like, do you think it is a slight thing to learn about the bird which he says
gods call chalcis, but men call cymindis,Hom. Il. 14.291 that it is much more correct for the same bird to be called chalcis than cymindis? Or to learn that the hill men call Batieia is called by the gods Myrina's tomb,Hom. Il. 2.813 f and many other such statements by Homer and other poets? But perhaps these matters are too high for us to understand; it is, I think, more within human power to investigate the names Scamandrius and Astyanax, and understand what kind of correctness he ascribes to these, which he says are the names of Hector's son. You recall, of course: the lines which contain the words to which I refer.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Which of the names of the boy do you imagine Homer thought was more correct, Astyanax or Scamandrius?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Look at it in this way: suppose you were asked, “Do the wise or the unwise give names more correctly?”

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: “The wise, obviously,” I should say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you think the women or the men of a city, regarded as a class in general, are the wiser?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: The men.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you not know that Homer says the child of Hector was called Astyanax by the men of Troy;Hom. Il. 22.506 so he must have been called Scamandrius by the women, since the men called him Astyanax?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, probably.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And Homer too thought the Trojan men were wiser than the women?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I suppose he did.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then he thought Astyanax was more rightly the boy's name than Scamandrius?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Let us, then, consider the reason for this. Does he not himself indicate the reason most admirably? For he says—
He alone defended their city and long walls.Hom. Il. 22.507But the verb is in the second person, addressed by Hecuba to Hector after his death. Therefore, as it seems, it is right to call the son of the defender Astyanax (Lord of the city), ruler of that which his father, as Homer says, defended.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is clear to me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Indeed? I do not yet understand about it myself, Hermogenes. Do you?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, by Zeus, I do not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, my good friend, did not Homer himself also give Hector his name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Why do you ask that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because that name seems to me similar to Astyanax, and both names seem to be Greek. For lord (a)/nac) and holder (e(/ktwr) mean nearly the same thing, indicating that they are names of a king; for surely a man is holder of that of which he is lord; for it is clear that he rules it and possesses it and holds it. Or does it seem to you that there is nothing in what I am saying, and am I wrong in imagining that I have found a clue to Homer's opinion about the correctness of names?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, by Zeus, you are not wrong, in my opinion; I think perhaps you have found a clue.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is right, I think, to call a lion's offspring a lion and a horse's offspring a horse. I am not speaking of prodigies, such as the birth of some other kind of creature from a horse, but of the natural offspring of each species after its kind. If a horse, contrary to nature, should bring forth a calf, the natural offspring of a cow, it should be called a calf, not a colt, nor if any offspring that is not human should be born from a human being, should that other offspring be called a human being; and the same applies to trees and all the rest. Do you not agree?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Good; but keep watch of me, and do not let me trick you; for by the same argument any offspring of a king should be called a king; and whether the same meaning is expressed in one set of syllables or another makes no difference; and if a letter is added or subtracted, that does not matter either, so long as the essence of the thing named remains in force and is made plain in the name.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Something quite simple. For instance, when we speak of the letters of the alphabet, you know, we speak their names, not merely the letters themselves, except in the case of four, e, u, o, w.In Plato's time the names epsilon, ypsilon, omicron, and omega were not yet in vogue. The names used were ei)=, u)=, ou)=,andw)=. We make names for all the other vowels and consonants by adding other letters to them; and so long as we include the letter in question and make its force plain, we may properly call it by that name, and that will designate it for us. Take beta, for instance, The addition of e(h), t(t), a(a) does no harm and does not prevent the whole name from making clear the nature of that letter which the lawgiver wished to designate; he knew so well how to give names to letters.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think you are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does not the same reasoning apply to a king? A king's son will probably be a king, a good man's good, a handsome man's handsome, and so forth; the offspring of each class will be of the same class, unless some unnatural birth takes place; so they should be called by the same names. But variety in the syllables is admissible, so that names which are the same appear different to the uninitiated, just as the physicians' drugs, when prepared with various colors and perfumes, seem different to us, though they are the same, but to the physician, who considers only their medicinal value, they seem the same, and he is not confused by the additions. So perhaps the man who knows about names considers their value and is not confused if some letter is added, transposed, or subtracted, or even if the force of the name is expressed in entirely different letters. So, for instance, in the names we were just discussing, Astyanax and Hector, none of the letters is the same, except T, but nevertheless they have the same meaning. And what letters has Archepolis (ruler of the city) in common with them? Yet it means the same thing; and there are many other names which mean simply “king.” Others again mean “general,” such as Agis (leader), Polemarchus (war-lord), and Eupolemus (good warrior); and others indicate physicians, as Iatrocles (famous physician) and Acesimbrotus (healer of mortals); and we might perhaps find many others which differ in syllables and letters, but express the same meaning. Do you think that is true, or not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: To those, then, who are born in accordance with nature the same names should be given.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how about those who are born contrary to nature as prodigies? For instance, when an impious son is born to a good and pious man, ought he not, as in our former example when a mare brought forth a calf, to have the designation of the class to which he belongs, instead of that of his parent?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the impious son of a pious father ought to receive the name of his class.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Not Theophilus (beloved of God) or Mnesitheus (mindful of God) or anything of that sort; but something of opposite meaning, if names are correct.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Most assuredly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: As the name of Orestes (mountain man) is undoubtedly correct, Hermogenes, whether it was given him by chance or by some poet who indicated by the name the fierceness, rudeness, and mountain-wildness of his nature.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: So it seems, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And his father's name also appears to be in accordance with nature.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: It seems so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, for Agamemnon (admirable for remaining) is one who would resolve to toil to the end and to endure, putting the finish upon his resolution by virtue. And a proof of this is his long retention of the host at Troy and his endurance. So the name Agamemnon denotes that this man is admirable for remaining. And so, too, the name of Atreus is likely to be correct; for his murder of Chrysippus and the cruelty of his acts to Thyestes are all damaging and ruinous (a)thra/) to his virtue. Now the form of his name is slightly deflected and hidden, so that it does not make the man's nature plain to every one; but to those who understand about names it makes the meaning of Atreus plain enough; for indeed in view of his stubbornness (a)teire/s) and fearlessness (a)/treston) and ruinous acts (a)thra/) the name is correctly given to him on every ground. And I think Pelops also has a fitting name; for this name means that he who sees only what is near deserves this designation.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why it is said of him that in murdering Myrtilus he was quite unable to forecast or foresee the ultimate effects upon his whole race, and all the misery with which it was overwhelmed, because he saw only the near at hand and the immediate— that is to say, pe/las (near)—in his eagerness to win by all means the hand of Hippodameia. And any one would think the name of Tantalus was given rightly and in accordance with nature, if the stories about him are true.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What are the stories?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The many terrible misfortunes that happened to him both in his life, the last of which was the utter overthrow of his country, and in Hades, after his death, the balancing (talantei/a) of the stone above his head, in wonderful agreement with his name; and it seems exactly as if someone who wished to call him most wretched (tala/ntaton) disguised the name and said Tantalus instead; in some such way as that chance seems to have affected his name in the legend. And his father also, who is said to be Zeus, appears to have a very excellent name, but it is not easy to understand; for the name of Zeus is exactly like a sentence; we divide it into two parts, and some of us use one part, others the other; for some call him Zena (*zh=na), and others Dia (*di/a); but the two in combination express the nature of the god, which is just what we said a name should be able to do. For certainly no one is so much the author of life (zh=n) for us and all others as the ruler and king of all. Thus this god is correctly named, through whom (di' o(/n) all living beings have the gift of life (zh=n). But, as I say, the name is divided, though it is one name, into the two parts, Dia and Zena. And it might seem, at first hearing, highly irreverent to call him the son of Cronus and reasonable to say that Zeus is the offspring of some great intellect; and so he is, for ko/ros (for *kro/nos) signifies not child, but the purity (kaqaro/n) and unblemished nature of his mind. And Cronus, according to tradition, is the son of Uranus; but the upward gaze is rightly called by the name urania (ou)rani/a), looking at the things above (o(rw= ta\ a)/nw), and the astronomers say, Hermogenes, that from this looking people acquire a pure mind, and Uranus is correctly named. If I remembered the genealogy of Hesiod and the still earlier ancestors of the gods he mentions, I would have gone on examining the correctness of their names until I had made a complete trial whether this wisdom which has suddenly come to me, I know not whence, will fail or not.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Indeed, Socrates, you do seem to me to be uttering oracles, exactly like an inspired prophet.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, Hermogenes, and I am convinced that the inspiration came to me from Euthyphro the Prospaltian. For I was with him and listening to him a long time early this morning. So he must have been inspired, and he not only filled my ears but took possession of my soul with his superhuman wisdom. So I think this is our duty: we ought today to make use of this wisdom and finish the investigation of names, but tomorrow, if the rest of you agree, we will conjure it away and purify ourselves, when we have found some one, whether priest or sophist, who is skilled in that kind of purifying.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I agree, for I should be very glad to hear the rest of the talk about names.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Very well. Then since we have outlined a general plan of investigation, where shall we begin, that we may discover whether the names themselves will bear witness that they are not at all distributed at haphazard, but have a certain correctness? Now the names of heroes and men might perhaps prove deceptive; for they are often given because they were names of ancestors, and in some cases, as we said in the beginning, they are quite inappropriate; many, too, are given as the expression of a prayer, such as Eutychides (fortunate), Sosias (saviour), Theophilus (beloved of God), and many others. I think we had better disregard such as these; but we are most likely to find the correct names in the nature of the eternal and absolute; for there the names ought to have been given with the greatest care, and perhaps some of them were given by a power more divine than is that of men.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think you are right, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then is it not proper to begin with the gods and see how the gods are rightly called by that name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is reasonable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Something of this sort, then, is what I suspect: I think the earliest men in Greece believed only in those gods in whom many foreigners believe today— sun, moon, earth, stars, and sky. They saw that all these were always moving in their courses and running, and so they called them gods (qeou/s) from this running (qei=n) nature; then afterwards, when they gained knowledge of the other gods, they called them all by the same name. Is that likely to be true, or not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, very likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What shall we consider next?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Spirits, obviously.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hermogenes, what does the name “spirits” really mean? See if you think there is anything in what I am going to say.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Go on and say it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you remember who Hesiod says the spirits are?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I do not recall it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor that he says a golden race was the first race of men to be born?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, I do know that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Well, he says of it:
But since Fate has covered up this race,
They are called holy spirits under the earth,
Noble, averters of evil, guardians of mortal men.Hes. WD 122 ff

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, I think he means that the golden race was not made of gold, but was good and beautiful. And I regard it as a proof of this that he further says we are the iron race.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Don't you suppose that if anyone of our day is good, Hesiod would say he was of that golden race?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Quite likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But the good are the wise, are they not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, they are the wise.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This, then, I think, is what he certainly means to say of the spirits: because they were wise and knowing (dah/mones) he called them spirits (dai/mones) and in the old form of our language the two words are the same. Now he and all the other poets are right, who say that when a good man dies he has a great portion and honor among the dead, and becomes a spirit, a name which is in accordance with the other name of wisdom. And so I assert that every good man, whether living or dead, is of spiritual nature, and is rightly called a spirit.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: And I, Socrates, believe I quite agree with you in that. But what is the word “hero”?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is easy to understand; for the name has been but slightly changed, and indicates their origin from love (e)/rws).

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, they were all born because a god fell in love with a mortal woman, or a mortal man with a goddess. Now if you consider the word “hero” also in the old Attic pronunciation,The old Attic alphabet was officially given up in favour of the Ionic alphabet in 404 or 403 B.C. The Attic for of the word “hero” is h(/ros, that of “Eros” e)/rws. Plato seems to think there was a change in pronunciation, as well as in spelling, and indeed that is quite possible. Or Plato may simply be confusing pronunciation with spelling, as he seems to do in several passages of this dialogue (cf. especially 410). you will understand better; for that will show you that it has been only slightly altered from the name of love (Eros), the source from which the heroes spring, to make a name for them. And either this is the reason why they are called heroes, or it is because they were wise and clever orators and dialecticians, able to ask questions (e)rwta=n), for ei)/rein is the same as le/gein (speak). Therefore, when their name is spoken in the Attic dialect, which I was mentioning just now, the heroes turn out to be orators and askers of questions, so that the heroic race proves to be a race of orators and sophists. That is easy to understand, but the case of men, and the reason why they are called men (a)/nqrwpoi), is more difficult. Can you tell me what it is?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, my friend, I cannot; and even if I might perhaps find out, I shall not try, because I think you are more likely to find out than I am.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You have faith in the inspiration of Euthyphro, it seems.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you are right in having it; for just at this very moment I think I have had a clever thought, and if I am not careful, before the day is over I am likely to be wiser than I ought to be. So pay attention. First we must remember in regard to names that we often put in or take out letters, making the names different from the meaning we intend, and we change the accent. Take, for instance, *dii\ fi/los; to change this from a phrase to a name, we took out the second iota and pronounced the middle syllable with the grave instead of the acute accent (Diphilus). In other instances, on the contrary, we insert letters and pronounce grave accents as acute.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now it appears to me that the name of men (a)/nqrwpos) underwent a change of that sort. It was a phrase, but became a noun when one letter, alpha, was removed and the accent of the last syllable was dropped.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you. The name “man” (a)/nqrwpos) indicates that the other animals do not examine, or consider, or look up at (a)naqrei=) any of the things that they see, but man has no sooner seen—that is, o)/pwpe—than he looks up at and considers that which he has seen. Therefore of all the animals man alone is rightly called man (a)/nqrwpos), because he looks up at (a)naqrei=) what he has seen (o)/pwpe).

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Of course. May I ask you about the next word I should like to have explained?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: It seems to me to come naturally next after those you have discussed. We speak of man's soul and body.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Let us try to analyze these, as we did the previous words.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You mean consider “soul” (yuxh/) and see why it is properly called by that name, and likewise “body” (sw=ma)?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: To speak on the spur of the moment, I think those who gave the soul its name had something of this sort in mind: they thought when it was present in the body it was the cause of its living, giving it the power to breathe and reviving it (a)nayu=xon), and when this revivifying force fails, the body perishes and comes to an end therefore, I think, they called it yuxh/. But—please keep still a moment. I fancy I see something which will carry more conviction to Euthyphro and his followers; for I think they would despise this attempt and would consider it cheap talk. Now see if you like the new one.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I am listening.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you think there is anything which holds and carries the whole nature of the body, so that it lives and moves, except the soul?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No; nothing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, and do you not believe the doctrine of Anaxagoras, that it is mind or soul which orders and holds the nature of all things?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then there would be an admirable fitness in calling that power which carries and holds (e)/xei) nature (fu/sin) fuse/xh and this may be refined and pronounced yuxh/.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly; and I think this is a more scientific explanation than the other.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, it is. But it seems actually absurd that the name was given with such truth.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Now what shall we say about the next word?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You mean “body” (sw=ma)?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think this admits of many explanations, if a little, even very little, change is made; for some say it is the tomb (sh=ma) of the soul, their notion being that the soul is buried in the present life; and again, because by its means the soul gives any signs which it gives, it is for this reason also properly called “sign” (sh=ma). But I think it most likely that the Orphic poets gave this name, with the idea that the soul is undergoing punishment for something; they think it has the body as an enclosure to keep it safe, like a prison, and this is, as the name itself denotes, the safe (sw=ma) for the soul, until the penalty is paid, and not even a letter needs to be changed.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think, Socrates, enough has been said about these words; but might we not consider the names of the gods in the same way in which you were speaking about that of Zeus a few minutes ago, and see what kind of correctness there is in them?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: By Zeus, Hermogenes, we, if we are sensible, must recognize that there is one most excellent kind, since of the gods we know nothing, neither of them nor of their names, whatever they may be, by which they call themselves, for it is clear that they use the true names. But there is a second kind of correctness, that we call them, as is customary in prayers, by whatever names and patronymics are pleasing to them, since we know no other. Now I think that is an excellent custom. So, if you like, let us first make a kind of announcement to the gods, saying that we are not going to investigate about them—for we do not claim to be able to do that—but about men, and let us inquire what thought men had in giving them their names; for in that there is no impiety.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think, Socrates, you are right; let us do as you say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we, then, begin with Hestia, according to custom?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is the proper thing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what would you say the man had in mind who gave Hestia her name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: By Zeus, I think that is no more easy question than the other.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: At any rate, my dear Hermogenes, the first men who gave names were no ordinary persons, but high thinkers and great talkers.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I am sure the names were given by men of that kind; and if foreign names are examined, the meaning of each of them is equally evident. Take, for instance, that which we call ou)si/a (reality, essence); some people call it e)ssi/a, and still others w)si/a. First, then, in connection with the second of these forms, it is reasonable that the essence of things be called Hestia; and moreover, because we ourselves say of that which partakes of reality “it is” (e)/stin), the name Hestia would be correct in this connection also; for apparently we also called ou)si/a (reality) e)ssi/a in ancient times. And besides, if you consider it in connection with sacrifices, you would come to the conclusion that those who established them understood the name in that way; for those who called the essence of things e)ssi/a would naturally sacrifice to Hestia first of all the gods. Those on the other hand, who say w)si/a would agree, well enough with Heracleitus that all things move and nothing remains still. So they would say the cause and ruler of things was the pushing power (w)qou=n), wherefore it had been rightly named w)si/a. But enough of this, considering that we know nothing. After Hestia it is right to consider Rhea and Cronus. The name of Cronus, however, has already been discussed. But perhaps I am talking nonsense.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Why, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: My friend, I have thought of a swarm of wisdom.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It sounds absurd, but I think there is some probability in it.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What is this probability?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I seem to have a vision of Heracleitus saying some ancient words of wisdom as old as the reign of Cronus and Rhea, which Homer said too.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Heracleitus says, you know, that all things move and nothing remains still, and he likens the universe to the current of a river, saying that you cannot step twice into the same stream.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Well, don't you think he who gave to the ancestors of the other gods the names “Rhea” and “Cronus” had the same thought as Heracleitus? Do you think he gave both of them the names of streams merely by chance? Just so Homer, too, says—
Ocean the origin of the gods, and their mother Tethys;Hom. Il. 14.201, 302 and I believe Hesiod says that also. Orpheus, too, says—
Fair-flowing Ocean was the first to marry,
and he wedded his sister Tethys, daughter of his mother.Orpheus FrSee how they agree with each other and all tend towards the doctrine of Heracleitus.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think there is something in what you say, Socrates; but I do not know what the name of Tethys means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, the name itself almost tells that it is the name of a spring somewhat disguised; for that which is strained (diattw/menon) and filtered (h)qou/menon) represents a spring, and the name Tethys is compounded of those two words.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is very neat, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Of course it is. But what comes next? Zeus we discussed before.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, speak of his brothers, Poseidon and Pluto, including also the other name of the latter.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think Poseidon's name was given by him who first applied it, because the power the sea restrained him as he was walking and hindered his advance; it acted as a bond (desmo/s) of his feet (podw=n). So he called the lord of this power Poseidon, regarding him as a foot-bond (posi/-desmon). The e is inserted perhaps for euphony. But possibly that may not be right; possibly two lambdas were originally pronounced instead of the sigma, because the god knew (ei)do/tos) many (polla/) things. Or it may be that from his shaking he was called the Shaker (o( sei/wn), and the pi and delta are additions. As for Pluto, he was so named as the giver of wealth (plou=tos), because wealth comes up from below out of the earth. And Hades—I fancy most people think that this is a name of the Invisible (a)eidh/s), so they are afraid and call him Pluto.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: And what do you think yourself, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think people have many false notions about the power of this god, and are unduly afraid of him. They are afraid because when we are once dead we remain in his realm for ever, and they are also terrified because the soul goes to him without the covering of the body. But I think all these facts, and the office and the name of the god, point in the same direction.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you my own view. Please answer this question: Which is the stronger bond upon any living being to keep him in any one place, desire, or compulsion?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Desire, Socrates, is much stronger.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you not believe there would be many fugitives from Hades, if he did not bind with the strongest bond those who go to him there?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Of course there would.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Apparently, then, if he binds them with the strongest bond, he binds them by some kind of desire, not by compulsion.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, that is plain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There are many desires, are there not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then he binds with the desire which is the strongest of all, if he is to restrain them with the strongest bond.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is there any desire stronger than the thought of being made a better man by association with some one?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, by Zeus, Socrates, there certainly is not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, Hermogenes, we must believe that this is the reason why no one has been willing to come away from that other world, not even the Sirens, but they and all others have been overcome by his enchantments, so beautiful, as it appears, are the words which Hades has the power to speak; and from this point of view this god is a perfect sophist and a great benefactor of those in his realm, he who also bestows such great blessings upon us who are on earth; such abundance surrounds him there below, and for this reason he is called Pluto. Then, too, he refuses to consort with men while they have bodies, but only accepts their society when the soul is pure of all the evils and desires of the body. Do you not think this shows him to be a philosopher and to understand perfectly that under these conditions he could restrain them by binding them with the desire of virtue, but that so long as they are infected with the unrest and madness of the body, not even his father Cronus could hold them to himself, though he bound them with his famous chains?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: There seems to be something in that, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the name “Hades” is not in the least derived from the invisible (a)eide/s), but far more probably from knowing (ei)de/nai) all noble things, and for that reason he was called Hades by the lawgiver.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Very well; what shall we say of Demeter, Hera, Apollo, Athena, Hephaestus, Ares, and the other gods

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Demeter appears to have been called Demeter, because like a mother (mh/thr) she gives the gift of food, and Hera is a lovely one (e)rath/), as indeed, Zeus is said to have married her for love. But perhaps the lawgiver had natural phenomena in mind, and called her Hera (*(/hra) as a disguise for a)h/r (air), putting the beginning at the end. You would understand, if you were to repeat the name Hera over and over. And Pherephatta!—How many people fear this name, and also Apollo! I imagine it is because they do not know about correctness of names. You see they change the name to Phersephone and its aspect frightens them. But really the name indicates that the goddess is wise; for since things are in motion (fero/mena), that which grasps (e)fapto/menon) and touches (e)pafw=n) and is able to follow them is wisdom. Pherepapha, or something of that sort, would therefore be the correct name of the goddess, because she is wise and touches that which is in motion (e)pafh\ tou= ferome/nou)—and this is the reason why Hades, who is wise, consorts with her, because she is wise—but people have altered her name, attaching more importance to euphony than to truth, and they call her Pherephatta. Likewise in the case of Apollo, as I say, many people are afraid because of the name of the god, thinking that it has some terrible meaning. Have you not noticed that?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly; what you say is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But really the name is admirably appropriate to the power of the god.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will try to tell you what I think about it; for no single name could more aptly indicate the four functions of the god, touching upon them all and in a manner declaring his power in music, prophecy, medicine, and archery.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Go on; you seem to imply that it is a remarkable name.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: His name and nature are in harmony; you see he is a musical god. For in the first place, purification and purgations used in medicine and in soothsaying, and fumigations with medicinal and magic drugs, and the baths and sprinklings connected with that sort of thing all have the single function of making a man pure in body and soul, do they not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But this is the god who purifies and washes away (a)paloou/wn) and delivers (a)polu/wn) from such evils, is he not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: With reference, then, to his acts of delivering and his washings, as being the physician of such diseases, he might properly be called Apoluon (a)palou/wn, the washer), and with reference to soothsaying and truth and simplicity—for the two are identical—he might most properly be called by the name the Thessalians use; for all Thessalians call the god Aplun. And because he is always by his archery controller of darts (bolw=n) he is ever darting (a)ei\ ba/llwn). And with reference to music we have to understand that alpha often signifies “together,” and here it denotes moving together in the heavens about the poles, as we call them, and harmony in song, which is called concord; for, as the ingenious musicians and astronomers tell us, all these things move together by a kind of harmony. And this god directs the harmony, making them all move together, among both gods and men; and so, just as we call the o(moke/leuqon (him who accompanies), and o(mo/koitin (bedfellow), by changing the o(mo to alpha, a)ko/louqon and a)/koitin, so also we called him Apollo who was Homopolo, and the second lambda was inserted, because without it the name sounded of disaster (a)polw=, a)po/lwla, etc.). Even as it is, some have a suspicion of this, because they do not properly regard the force of the name, and therefore they fear it, thinking that it denotes some kind of ruin. But in fact, as was said, the name touches upon all the qualities of the god, as simple, ever-darting, purifying, and accompanying. The Muses and music in general are named, apparently, from mw=sqai, searching, and philosophy; and Leto from her gentleness, because whatever is asked of her, she is willing (e)qelh/mwn). But perhaps her name is Letho, as she is called by many foreigners; and those who call her by that name seem to do so on account of the mild and gentle (lei=on, *lhqw/) kindness of her character. Artemis appears to get her name from her healthy (a)rteme/s) and well-ordered nature, and her love of virginity; or perhaps he who named her meant that she is learned in virtue (a)reth/), or possibly, too, that she hates sexual intercourse (a)/roton misei=) of man and woman; or he who gave the goddess her name may have given it for any or all of these reasons.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What of Dionysus and Aphrodite?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You ask great things of me, son of Hipponicus. You see there is both a serious and a facetious account of the form of the name of these deities. You will have to ask others for the serious one; but there is nothing to hinder my giving you the facetious account, for the gods also have a sense of humor. Dionysus, the giver (didou/s) of wine (oi)=nos), might be called in jest Didoinysus, and wine, because it makes most drinkers think (oi)/esqai) they have wit (nou=s) when they have not, might very justly be called Oeonus (oi)o/nous). As for Aphrodite, we need not oppose Hesiod; we can accept his derivation of the name from her birth out of the foam (a)frou=).

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: But surely you, as an Athenian, will not forget Athena, nor Hephaestus and Ares.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is not likely.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is easy to tell the reason of one of her two names.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What name?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We call her Pallas, you know.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Those of us are right, I fancy, who think this name is derived from armed dances, for lifting oneself or anything else from the ground or in the hands is called shaking (pa/llein) and being shaken, or dancing and being danced.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So that is the reason she is called Pallas.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: And rightly called so. But what can you say of her other name?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You mean Athena?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
Hermogenes
sp.p: And how do you explain Hephaestus?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You ask about “the noble master of light”?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hephaestus is Phaestus, with the eta added by attraction; anyone could see that, I should think.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Very likely, unless some other explanation occurs to you, as it probably will.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: To prevent that, ask about Ares.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I do ask.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Ares, then, if you like, would be named for his virility and courage, or for his hard and unbending nature, which is called a)/rraton; so Ares would be in every way a fitting name for the god of war.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For God's sake, let us leave the gods, as I am afraid to talk about them; but ask me about any others you please, “that you may see what” Euthyphro's “horses are.”Cf. Hom. Il. 5.221, Hom. Il. 8.105.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I will do so, but first one more god. I want to ask you about Hermes, since Cratylus says I am not Hermogenes (son of Hermes). Let us investigate the name of Hermes, to find out whether there is anything in what he says.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, this name “Hermes” seems to me to have to do with speech; he is an interpreter (h(rmhneu/s) and a messenger, is wily and deceptive in speech, and is oratorical. All this activity is concerned with the power of speech. Now, as I said before, ei)/rein denotes the use of speech; moreover, Homer often uses the word e)mh/sato, which means “contrive.” From these two words, then, the lawgiver imposes upon us the name of this god who contrived speech and the use of speech—ei)/reinmeans “speak”— and tells us: “Ye human beings, he who contrived speech (ei)/rein e)mh/sato) ought to be called Eiremes by you.” We, however, have beautified the name, as we imagine, and call him Hermes. Iris also seems to have got her name from ei)/rein, because she is a messenger.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: By Zeus, I believe Cratylus was right in saying I was not Hermogenes; I certainly am no good contriver of speech.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it is reasonable, my friend, that Pan is the double-natured son of Hermes.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You know that speech makes all things (pa=n) known and always makes them circulate and move about, and is twofold, true and false.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, the true part is smooth and divine and dwells aloft among the gods, but falsehood dwells below among common men, is rough and like the tragic goatThe chorus of the primitive performances from which tragedy developed appeared as satyrs, clad in goat-skins. Hence the name tragw|di/a (goat-song). The adjective tragiko/s may mean either “goat-like” or “tragic.” In this passage it has both meanings.; for tales and falsehoods are most at home there, in the tragic life.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then Pan, who declares and always moves (a)ei\ polw=n) all, is rightly called goat-herd (ai)po/los), being the double-natured son of Hermes, smooth in his upper parts, rough and goat-like in his lower parts. And Pan, if he is the son of Hermes, is either speech or the brother of speech, and that brother resembles brother is not at all surprising. But, as I said, my friend, let us get away from the gods.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: From such gods as those, if you like, Socrates; but why should you not tell of another kind of gods, such as sun, moon, stars, earth, ether, air, fire, water, the seasons, and the year?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are imposing a good many tasks upon me; however, if it will give you pleasure, I am willing.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: It will give me pleasure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What, then, do you wish first? Shall we discuss the sun (*(/hlios), as you mentioned it first?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think it would be clearer if we were to use the Doric form of the name. The Dorians call it *(/alios. Now a(/lios might be derived from collecting (a(li/zein) men when he rises, or because he always turns (a)ei\ ei(lei=n) about the earth in his course, or because he variegates the products of the earth, for variegate is identical with ai)ollei=n.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: And what of the moon, Selene?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That name appears to put Anaxagoras in an uncomfortable position.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, it seems to have anticipated by many years the recent doctrine of Anaxagoras, that the moon receives its light from the sun.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: *se/las (gleam) and fw=s (light) are the same thing.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now the light is always new and old about the moon, if the Anaxagoreans are right; for they say the sun, in its continuous course about the moon, always sheds new light upon it, and the light of the previous month persists.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The moon is often called *selanai/a.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because it has always a new and old gleam (se/la ne/on te kai\ e(/non) the very most fitting name for it would be *selaenoneoa/eia, which has been compressed into *selanai/a.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is a regular opera bouffe name, Socrates. But what have you to say of the month (mh/n) and the stars?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The word “month” (mei/s) would be properly pronounced mei/hs, from meiou=sqai, “to grow less,” and I think the stars (a)/stera) get their name from a)straph/ (lightning). But a)straph/, because it turns our eyes upwards (ta\ w)=pa a)nastre/qei), would be called a)nastrwph/, which is now pronounced more prettily a)straph/.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: And what of pu=r (fire) and u(/dwr (water)?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: *pu=r is too much for me. It must be that either the muse of Euthyphro has deserted me or this is a very difficult word. Now just note the contrivance I introduce in all cases like this which are too much for me.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What contrivance?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you. Answer me; can you tell the reason of the word pu=r?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Not I, by Zeus.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: See what I suspect about it. I know that many Greeks, especially those who are subject to the barbarians, have adopted many foreign words.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If we should try to demonstrate the fitness of those words in accordance with the Greek language, and not in accordance with the language from which they are derived, you know we should get into trouble.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Naturally.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, this word pu=r is probably foreign; for it is difficult to connect it with the Greek language, and besides, the Phrygians have the same word, only slightly altered. The same is the case with u(/dwr (water), ku/wn (dog), and many other words.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, that is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So we must not propose forced explanations of these words, though something might be said about them. I therefore set aside pu=r and u(/dwr in this way. But is air called a)h/r because it raises (ai)/rei) things from the earth, or because it is always flowing (a)ei\ r(ei=), or because wind arises from its flow? The poets call the winds a)h/tas, “blasts.” Perhaps the poet means to say “air-flow” (a)hto/rroun), as he might say “wind-flow” (pneumato/rroun). The word ai)/qhr (ether) I understand in this way: because it always runs and flows about the air (a)ei\ qei= peri\ to\n a)e/ra r(e/on), it may properly be called a)eiqeh/ra. The word gh= (earth) shows the meaning better in the form gai=a; for gai=a is a correct word for “mother,” as Homer says, for he uses gega/asin to mean gegenh=sqai (be born). Well, now what came next?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: The seasons, Socrates, and the two words for year.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The word w(=rai (seasons) should be pronounced in the old Attic fashion, o(/rai, if you wish to know the probable meaning; *h*o*r*a*i exist to divide winters and summers and winds and the fruits of the earth; and since they divide (o(ri/zousi), they would rightly be called o(/rai. The two words for year, e)niauto/s and e)/tos, are really one. For that which brings to light within itself the plants and animals, each in its turn, and examines them, is called by some e)niauto/s, because of its activity within itself (e)n e(autw=|), and by others e)/tos, because it examines (e)ta/zei), just as we saw before that the name of Zeus was divided and some said *di/a and others *zh=na. The whole phrase is “that which examines within itself” (to\ e)n a(utw=| e)ta/zon), and this one phrase is divided in speech so that the two words e)niauto/s and e)/tos are formed from one phrase.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Truly, Socrates, you are going ahead at a great rate.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, I fancy I am already far along on the road of wisdom.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I am sure you are.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You will be surer presently.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Now after the class of words you, have explained, I should like to examine the correctness of the noble words that relate to virtue, such as wisdom, intelligence, justice, and all the others of that sort.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are stirring up a mighty tribe of words, my friend; however, since I have put on the lion helmet, I must not play the coward, but must, it seems, examine wisdom, intelligence, thought, knowledge, and all the other noble words of which you speak.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly we must not stop until that is done.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: By dog, I believe I have a fine intuition which has just come to me, that the very ancient men who invented names were quite like most of the present philosophers who always get dizzy as they turn round and round in their search for the nature of things, and then the things seem to them to turn round and round and be in motion. They think the cause of this belief is not an affection within themselves, but that the nature of things really is such that nothing is at rest or stable, but everything is flowing and moving and always full of constant motion and generation. I say this because I thought of it with reference to all these words we are now considering.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How is that, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps you did not observe that the names we just mentioned are given under the assumption that the things named are moving and flowing and being generated.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, I did not notice that at all.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Surely the first one we mentioned is subject to such assumptions.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What is the word ?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Wisdom (fro/nhsis); for it is perception (no/hsis) of motion (fora=s) and flowing (r(ou=); or it might be understood as benefit (o)/nhsis) of motion (fora=s); in either case it has to do with motion. And gnw/mh (thought), if you please, certainly denotes contemplation and consideration of generation (gonh=s nw/mhsis); for to consider is the same as to contemplate. Or, if you please, no/hsis (intelligence) is merely e(/sis (desire) tou= neou= (of the new); but that things are new shows that they are always being generated; therefore the soul's desire for generation is declared by the giver of the name neo/esis; for in antiquity the name was not no/hsis, but two epsilons had to be spoken instead of the eta. *swfrosu/nh (self-restraint) is swthri/a (salvation) of fro/nhsis (wisdom), which we have just been discussing. And e)pisth/mh (knowledge) indicates that the soul which is of any account accompanies (e(/petai) things in their motion, neither falling behind them nor running in front of them; therefore we ought to insert an epsilon and call it e)pei+sth/mh. *su/nesis (intelligence) in its turn is a kind of reckoning together; when one says sunie/nai (understand), the same thing as e)pi/stasqai is said; for sunie/nai means that the soul goes with things. Certainly sofi/a (wisdom) denotes the touching of motion. This word is very obscure and of foreign origin; but we must remember that the poets often say of something which begins to advance e)su/qh (it rushed). There was a famous Laconian whose name was *sou=s (Rush), for this is the Laconian word for rapid motion. Now sofi/a signifies the touching (e)pafh/) of this rapid motion, the assumption being that things are in motion. And the word a)gaqo/n (good) is intended to denote the admirable (a)gasto/n) in all nature. For since all things are in motion, they possess quickness and slowness; now not all that is swift, but only part of it, is admirable; this name a)gaqo/n is therefore given to the admirable (a)gasto/n) part of the swift (qoou=).It is easy to conjecture that the word dikaiasu/nh applies to the understanding (su/nesis) of the just (tou= diai/on) but the word di/kaion (just) is itself difficult. Up to a certain point, you see, many men seem to agree about it, but beyond that they differ. For those who think the universe is in motion believe that the greater part of it is of such a nature as to be a mere receptacle, and that there is some element which passes through all this, by means of which all created things are generated. And this element must be very rapid and very subtle; for it could not pass through all the universe unless it were very subtle, so that nothing could keep it out, and it must be very swift, so that all other things are relatively at rest. Since, then, it superintends and passes through (diai+o/n) all other things, this is rightly called by the name di/kaion, the sound of the kappa being added merely for the sake of euphony. Up to this point, as I said just now, many men agree about justice (di/kaion); and I, Hermogenes, being very much in earnest about it, have persistently asked questions and have been told in secret teachings that this is justice, or the cause—for that through which creation takes place is a cause—and some one told me that it was for this reason rightly called Zeus (*di/a). But when, after hearing this, I nevertheless ask them quietly, “What then, my most excellent friend, if this is true, is justice?” they think I am asking too many questions and am leaping over the trenches.A trench was the limit of the leap for the pentathletes. They say I have been told enough; they try to satisfy me by saying all sorts of different things, and they no longer agree. For one says the sun is justice, for the sun alone superintends all things, passing through and burning (diai+o/nta kai\ kai/onta) them. Then when I am pleased and tell this to some one, thinking it is a fine answer, he laughs at me and asks if I think there is no justice among men when the sun has set. So I beg him to tell me what he thinks it is, and he says “Fire.” But this is not easy to understand. He says it is not actual fire, but heat in the abstract that is in the fire. Another man says he laughs at all these notions, and that justice is what Anaxagoras says it is, mind; for mind, he says, is ruled only by itself, is mixed with nothing, orders all things, and passes through them. Then, my friend, I am far more perplexed than before I undertook to learn about the nature of justice. But I think the name—and that was the subject of our investigation—was given for the reasons I have mentioned.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think, Socrates, you must have heard this from some one and are not inventing it yourself.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how about the rest of my talk?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I do not at all think you had heard that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
Hermogenes
sp.p: Very likely, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again, the word qa/llein (flourish) seems to me to figure the rapid and sudden growth of the young. Something of that sort the namegiver has reproduced in the name, which he compounded of qei=n (run) and a(/llesqai (jump). You do not seem to notice how I rush along outside of the race-course, when I get on smooth ground. But we still have plenty of subjects left which seem to be serious.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: One of which is to see what the word te/xnh (art, science) means.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does not this denote possession of mind, if you remove the tau and insert omicron between the chi and the nu and the nu and the eta (making e)xono/h)?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: It does it very poorly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: My friend, you do not bear in mind that the original words have before now been completely buried by those who wished to dress them up, for they have added and subtracted letters for the sake of euphony and have distorted the words in every way for ornamentation or merely in the lapse of time. Do you not, for instance, think it absurd that the letter rho is inserted in the word ka/aptron (mirror)? I think that sort of thing is the work of people who care nothing for truth, but only for the shape of their mouths; so they keep adding to the original words until finally no human being can understand what in the world the word means. So the sphinx, for instance, is called sphinx, instead of phix, and there are many other examples.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, that is true, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if we are permitted to insert and remove any letters we please in words, it will be perfectly easy to fit any name to anything.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, quite true. But I think you, as a wise director, must observe the rule of moderation and probability.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I should like to do so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I, too, Hermogenes. But do not, my friend, demand too much precision, lest you “enfeeble me of my sight.”Hom.
