Il. 6.265 For now that te/xnh (art) is disposed of, I am nearing the loftiest height of my subject, when once we have investigated mhxanh/(contrivance). For I think mhxanh/ signifies a)/nein e)pi\ polu/ (much accomplishment); for mh=kos (length) has about the same meaning as to\ polu/ (much), and the name mhxanh/ is composed of these two, mh=kos and a)/nein. But, as I was just saying, we must go on to the loftiest height of our subject; we must search for the meaning of the words a)reth/ (virtue) and kaki/a (wickedness). Now one of them I cannot yet see; but the other seems to be quite clear, since it agrees with everything we have said before. For inasmuch as all things are in motion, everything that moves badly (kakw=s i)o/n) would be evil (kaki/a); and when this evil motion in relation to its environment exists in the soul, it receives the general name kaki/a (evil) in the special sense of wickedness. But the nature of evil motion (kakw=s i)e/nai) is made clear, I think, also in the word deili/a (cowardice), which we have not yet discussed. We passed it by, when we ought to have examined it after a)ndrei/a (courage); and I fancy we passed over a good many other words. Now the meaning of deili/a is “a strong bond of the soul”; for li/an (excessively) is, in a way, expressive of strength; so deili/a would be the excessive or greatest bond (desmo/s, dei=n) of the soul; and so, too, a)pori/a (perplexity) is an evil, as is everything, apparently, which hinders motion and progress (poreu/esqai). This, then, seems to be the meaning of evil motion (kakw=s i)e/nai), that advance is halting and impeded; and the soul that is infected by it becomes filled with wickedness (kaki/a). If these are the reasons for the name of wickedness, virtue (a)reth/) would be the opposite of this; it would signify first ease of motion, and secondly that the flow of the good soul is always unimpeded, and therefore it has received this name, which designates that which always flows (a)ei\ r(e/on) without let or hindrance. It is properly called a)eireith/, or perhaps also ai(reth/, indicating that this condition is especially to be chosen; but it has been compressed and is pronounced a)reth/. Perhaps you will say this is another invention of mine; but I say if what I said just now about kaki/a is right, this about the name of a)reth/ is right too.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: But what is the meaning of the word kako/n which you used in many of your derivations?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: By Zeus, I think it is a strange word and hard to understand; so I apply to it that contrivance of mine.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What contrivance?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The claim of foreign origin, which I advance in this case as in those others.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Well, probably you are right. But, if you please, let us drop these words and try to discover the reasons for the words kalo/n (beautiful, noble) and ai)sxro/n (base).

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think the meaning of ai)sxro/n is clear, and this also agrees with what has been said before. For the giver of names appears to me throughout to denounce that which hinders and restrains things from flowing, and in this instance he gave to that which always restrains the flow (a)ei\ i)/sxei to\n r(ou=n) this name a)eisxorou=n, which is now compressed and pronounced ai)sxro/n.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What about kalo/n?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is harder to understand, and yet it expresses its meaning: it has been altered merely in accent and in the length of the O.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think this word denotes intellect.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, what do you think is the cause why anything is called by a name? Is it not the power which gave the name?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Why, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not that power the intellect either of gods or of men or both?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are not that which called things by name and that which calls them by name (to\ kalou=n) the same thing, namely intellect?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, clearly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are not all works which are done by mind and intelligence worthy of praise, and those that are not done by them worthy of blame?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does not the medical power perform medical works and the power of carpentry works of carpentry? Do you agree to that?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the beautiful performs beautiful works?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: It must do so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the beautiful is, we say, intellect?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then this name, the beautiful, is rightly given to mind, since it accomplishes the works which we call beautiful and in which we delight.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What further words of this sort are left for us?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Those that are related to the good and the beautiful, such as sumfe/ronta (advantageous), lusitelou=nta (profitable), w)fe/lima (useful), kerdale/a (gainful), and their opposites.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You might by this time be able to find the meaning of sumfe/ronta by yourself in the light of the previous explanations, for it appears to be own brother to e)pisth/mh. It means nothing else but the motion (fora/) of the soul in company with the world, and naturally things which are done by such a power are called sumfe/ronta and su/mfora because they are carried round with (sumperife/resqai) the world. But kerdale/on is from ke/rdos (gain). If you restore nu in the word ke/rdos in place of the delta, the meaning is plain; it signifies good, but in another way. Because it passes through and is mingled (kera/nnutai) with all things, he who named it gave it this name which indicates that function; but he inserted a delta instead of nu and said ke/rdos.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: And what is lusitelou=n?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I do not think, Hermogenes, the name-giver gives the meaning to lusitelou=n which it has in the language of tradesfolk, when profit sets free (a)polu/ei) the sum invested, but he means that because it is the swiftest thing in the world it does not allow things to remain at rest and does not allow the motion to come to any end (te/los) of movement or to stop or pause, but always, if any end of the motion is attempted, it sets it free, making it unceasing and immortal. It is in this sense, I think, that the good is dubbed lusitelou=n, for it frees (lu/ei) the end (te/los) of the motion. But the word w)fe/limon is a foreign one, which Homer often uses in the verbal form o)fe/llein. This is a synonym of “increase” and “create.”

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What shall be our explanations of the opposites of these?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Those of them that are mere negatives, need, I think, no discussion.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Which are those?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Disadvantageous, useless, unprofitable, and ungainful.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But blabero/n (harmful) and zhmiw=des (hurtful) do need it.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And blabero/n means that which harms (bla/pton) the flow (r(ou=n); but bla/pton means “wishing to fasten” (a(/ptein), and a(/ptein is the same thing as dei=n (bind), which the name-giver constantly finds fault with. Now to\ boulo/menon a(/ptein r(ou=n (that which wishes to fasten the flow) would most correctly be called boulapterou=n, but is called blabero/n merely, as I think, to make it prettier.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Elaborate names these are, Socrates, that result from your method. Just now, when you pronounced boulapterou=n, you looked as if you had made up your mouth to whistle the flute-prelude of the hymn to Athena.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Not I, Hermogenes, am responsible, but those who gave the name.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: True. Well, what is the origin of zhmiw=des?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What can the origin of zhmiw=des be? See, Hermogenes, how true my words are when I say that by adding and taking away letters people alter the sense of words so that even by very slight changes they sometimes make them mean the opposite of what they meant before; as, for instance, in the case of the word de/on (obligation, right), for that just occurred to me and I was reminded of it by what I was going to say to you, that this fine modern language of ours has turned de/on and also zhmiw=des round, so that each has the opposite of its original meaning, whereas the ancient language shows clearly the real sense of both words.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you. You know that our ancestors made good use of the sounds of iota and delta, and that is especially true of the women, who are most addicted to preserving old forms of speech. But nowadays people change iota to eta or epsilon, and delta to zeta, thinking they have a grander sound.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For instance, in the earliest times they called day i(me/ra, others said e(me/ra, and now they say h(me/ra.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Only the ancient word discloses the intention of the name-giver, don't you know? For day comes out of darkness to men; they welcome it and long (i(mei/rousi) for it, and so they called it i(me/ra.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is clear.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But now h(me/ra is masquerading so that you could not guess its meaning. Why, some people think day is called h(me/ra because it makes things gentle (h(/mera).

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I believe they do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you know the ancients called zugo/n (yoke) duogo/n.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And zugo/n conveys no clear meaning, but the name duogo/n is quite properly given to that which binds two together for the purpose of draught; now, however, we say zugo/n. There are a great many other such instances.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, that is plain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Similarly the word de/on (obligation) at first, when spoken in this way, denotes the opposite of all words connected with the good; for although it is a form of good, de/on seems to be a bond (desmo/s) and hindrance of motion, own brother, as it were, toblabero/n.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, Socrates, it certainly does seem so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But it does not, if you employ the ancient word, which is more likely to be right than the present one. You will find that it agrees with the previous words for “good,” if instead of the epsilon you restore the iota, as it was in old times for dio/n (going through), not de/on, signifies good, which the name-giver praises. And so the giver of names does not contradict himself, but de/on (obligation, right), w)fe/limon (useful), lusitelou=n (profitable), kerdale/on (gainful), a)gaqo/n (good), cumfe/ron (advantageous), and eu)/poron (prosperous), are plainly identical, signifying under different names the principle of arrangement and motion which has constantly been praised, whereas the principle of constraint and bondage is found fault with. And likewise in the case of zhmiw=des, if you restore the ancient delta in place of the zeta, you will see that the name, pronounced dhmiw=des, was given to that which binds motion (dou=nti to\ i)o/n).

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What of h(donh/ (pleasure) and lu/ph (pain) and e)piqumi/a (desire), and the like, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I do not think they are at all difficult, Hermogenes, for h(donh/ appears to have this name because it is the action that tends towards advantage (h( pro\s th\n o)/nhsin tei/nousa); the delta is inserted, so that we say h(donh/ instead of h(onh/. *lu/ph appears to have received its name from the dissolution (dia/lusis) of the body which takes place through pain. *)ani/a (sorrow) is that which hinders motion (i)e/nai). *)alghdw/n (distress) is, I think, a foreign word, derived from a)lgeino/s (distressing). *)odu/nh (grief) appears to be so called from the putting on of pain (th=s e)ndu/sews th=s lu/phs). *)axqhdw/n (vexation) has a name, as anyone can see, made in the likeness of the weight (a)/xqos, burden) which vexation imposes upon motion. *xara/ (joy) seems to have its name from the plenteous diffusion (dia/xusis) of the flow of the soul. *te/ryis (delight) is from terpno/n (delightful); and terpno/n is called from the creeping (e(/ryis) of the soul, which is likened to a breath (pnoh/), and would properly be called e(/rpnoun, but the name has been changed in course of time to terpno/n. *eu)frosu/nh(mirth) needs no explanation, for it is clear to anyone that from the motion of the soul in harmony (eu)=) with the universe, it received the name eu)ferosu/nh, as it rightfully is; but we call it eufrosu/nh. Nor is there any difficulty about e)piqumi/a (desire), for this name was evidently given to the power that goes (i)ou=sa) into the soul (qumo/s). And qumo/s has its name from the raging (qu/sis) and boiling of the soul. The name i(/meros (longing) was given to the stream (r(ou=s) which most draws the soul; for because it flows with a rush (i(e/menos) and with a desire for things and thus draws the soul on through the impulse of its flowing, all this power gives it the name of i(/meros. And the word po/qos (yearning) signifies that it pertains not to that which is present, but to that which is elsewhere (a)/lloqi/ pou) or absent, and therefore the same feeling which is called i(/meros when its object is present, is called po/qos when it is absent. And e)/rws (love) is so called because it flows in (e)srei=) from without, and this flowing is not inherent in him who has it, but is introduced through the eyes; for this reason it was in ancient times called e)/sros, from e)srei=n—for we used to employ omicron instead of omega—but now it is called e)/rws through the change of omicron to omega. Well, what more is there that you want to examine?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What is your view about do/ca (opinion) and the like?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: *do/ca is derived either from the pursuit (di/wcis) which the soul carries on as it pursues the knowledge of the nature of things, or from the shooting of the bow (to/con); the latter is more likely; at any rate oi)/hsis (belief) supports this view, for it appears to mean the motion (oi)=sis) of the soul towards the essential nature of every individual thing, just as boulh/ (intention) denotes shooting (bolh/) and bou/lesqai (wish), as well as bouleu/esqai (plan), denotes aiming at something. All these words seem to follow do/ca and to express the idea of shooting, just as a)bouli/a (ill-advisedness), on the other hand, appears to be a failure to hit, as if a person did not shoot or hit that which he shot at or wished or planned or desired.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think you are hurrying things a bit, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, for I am running the last lap now. But I think I must still explain a)na/gkh (compulsion) and e(kou/sion (voluntary) because they naturally come next. Now by the word e(kou/sion is expressed the yielding (ei)=kon) and not opposing, but, as I say, yielding to the motion which is in accordance with the will; but the compulsory (to\ a)nagkai=on) and resistant, being contrary to the will, is associated with error and ignorance; so it is likened to walking through ravines (a)/gkh), because they are hard to traverse, rough, and rugged, and retard motion; the word a)nagkai=on may, then, originate in a comparison with progress through a ravine. But let us not cease to use my strength, so long as it lasts and do not you cease from asking questions.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I ask, then, about the greatest and noblest words, truth (a)lh/qeia), falsehood (yeu=dos), being (to\ o)/n), and why name, the subject of our whole discourse, has the name o)/noma.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does the word mai/sqai (search) mean anything to you?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, it means “seek.”

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The word o)/noma seems to be a word composed from a sentence signifying “this is a being about which our search is.” You can recognize that more readily in the adjective o)nomasto/n, for that says clearly that this is o)/n ou(= ma/sma e)sti/n (being of which the search is). And a)lh/qeia (truth) is like the others; for the divine motion of the universe is, I think, called by this name, a)lh/qeia, because it is a divine wandering qei/a a)/lh. But yeu=dos (falsehood) is the opposite of motion; for once more that which is held back and forced to be quiet is found fault with, and it is compared to slumberers (eu(/ousi); but the addition of the psi conceals the meaning of the word. The words to\ o)/n (being) and ou)si/a (existence) agree with a)lhqh/s with the loss of iota, for they mean “going” (i)o/n). And ou)k o)/n (not being) means ou)k i)o/n (not going), and indeed some people pronounce it so.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think you have knocked these words to pieces manfully, Socrates; but if anyone should ask you what propriety or correctness there was in these words that you have employed—i)o/n and re(/on and dou=n—

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What answer should I make? Is that your meaning?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, exactly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We acquired just now one way of making an answer with a semblance of sense in it.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: What way was that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Saying, if there is a word we do not know about, that it is of foreign origin. Now this may be true of some of them, and also on account of the lapse of time it may be impossible to find out about the earliest words; for since words get twisted in all sorts of ways, it would not be in the least wonderful if the ancient Greek word should be identical with the modern foreign one.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: That is not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is indeed quite probable. However, we must play the gameA proverbial expression. and investigate these questions vigorously. But let us bear in mind that if a person asks about the words by means of which names are formed, and again about those by means of which those words were formed, and keeps on doing this indefinitely, he who answers his questions will at last give up; will he not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now at what point will he be right in giving up and stopping? Will it not be when he reaches the names which are the elements of the other names and words? For these, if they are the elements, can no longer rightly appear to be composed of other names. For instance, we said just now that a)gaqo/n was composed of a)gasto/n and qoo/n; and perhaps we might say that qoo/n was composed of other words, and those of still others; but if we ever get hold of a word which is no longer composed of other words, we should be right ill saying that we had at last reached an element, and that we must no longer refer to other words for its derivation.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think you are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are, then, these words about which you are now asking elements, and must we henceforth investigate their correctness by some other method?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Probably.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, probably, Hermogenes; at any rate, all the previous words were traced back to these. But if this be true, as I think it is, come to my aid again and help me in the investigation, that I may not say anything foolish in declaring what principle must underlie the correctness of the earliest names.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Go on, and I will help you to the best of my ability.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think you agree with me that there is but one principle of correctness in all names, the earliest as well as the latest, and that none of them is any more a name than the rest.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now the correctness of all the names we have discussed was based upon the intention of showing the nature of the things named.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And this principle of correctness must be present in all names, the earliest as well as the later ones, if they are really to be names.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But the later ones, apparently, were able to accomplish this by means of the earlier ones.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, how can the earliest names, which are not as yet based upon any others, make clear to us the nature of things, so far as that is possible, which they must do if they are to be names at all? Answer me this question: If we had no voice or tongue, and wished to make things clear to one another, should we not try, as dumb people actually do, to make signs with our hands and head and person generally?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes. What other method is there, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If we wished to designate that which is above and is light, we should, I fancy, raise our hand towards heaven in imitation of the nature of the thing in question; but if the things to be designated were below or heavy, we should extend our hands towards the ground; and if we wished to mention a galloping horse or any other animal, we should, of course, make our bodily attitudes as much like theirs as possible.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think you are quite right; there is no other way.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For the expression of anything, I fancy, would be accomplished by bodily imitation of that which was to be expressed.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when we wish to express anything by voice or tongue or mouth, will not our expression by these means be accomplished in any given instance when an imitation of something is accomplished by them?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think that is inevitable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A name, then, it appears, is a vocal imitation of that which is imitated, and he who imitates with his voice names that which he imitates.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think that is correct.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: By Zeus, I do not think it is quite correct, yet, my friend.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We should be obliged to agree that people who imitate sheep and cocks and other animals were naming those which they imitate.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, so we should.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you think that is correct?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, I do not; but, Socrates, what sort of an imitation is a name?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In the first place we shall not, in my opinion, be making names, if we imitate things as we do in music, although musical imitation also is vocal; and secondly we shall make no names by imitating that which music imitates. What I mean is this: all objects have sound and shape, and many have color, have they not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, the art of naming is not employed in the imitation of those qualities, and has nothing to do with them. The arts which are concerned with them are music and design, are they not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Here is another point. Has not each thing an essential nature, just as it has a color and the other qualities we just mentioned? Indeed, in the first place, have not color and sound and all other things which may properly be said to exist, each and all an essential nature?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, if anyone could imitate this essential nature of each thing by means of letters and syllables, he would show what each thing really is, would he not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what will you call him who can do this, as you called the others musician and painter? What will you call this man?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think, Socrates, he is what we have been looking for all along, the name-maker.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If that is the case, is it our next duty to consider whether in these names about which you were asking—flow, motion, and restraint—the namemaker grasps with his letters and syllables the reality of the things named and imitates their essential nature, or not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, let us see whether those are the only primary names, or there are others.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I think there are others.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, most likely there are. Now what is the method of division with which the imitator begins his imitation? Since the imitation of the essential nature is made with letters and syllables, would not the most correct way be for us to separate the letters first, just as those who undertake the practice of rhythms separate first the qualities of the letters, then those of the syllables, and then, but not till then, come to the study of rhythms?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Must not we, too, separate first the vowels, then in their several classes the consonants or mutes, as they are called by those who specialize in phonetics, and also the letters which are neither vowels nor mutes, as well as the various classes that exist among the vowels themselves? And when we have made all these divisions properly, we must in turn give names to the things which ought to have them, if there are any names to which they can all, like the letters, be referred, from which it is possible to see what their nature is and whether there are any classes among them, as there are among letters. When we have properly examined all these points, we must know how to apply each letter with reference to its fitness, whether one letter is to be applied to one thing or many are to be combined; just as painters, when they wish to produce an imitation, sometimes use only red, sometimes some other color, and sometimes mix many colors, as when they are making a picture of a man or something of that sort, employing each color, I suppose, as they think the particular picture demands it. In just this way we, too, shall apply letters to things, using one letter for one thing, when that seems to be required, or many letters together, forming syllables, as they are called, and in turn combining syllables, and by their combination forming nouns and verbs. And from nouns and verbs again we shall finally construct something great and fair and complete. Just as in our comparison we made the picture by the art of painting, so now we shall make language by the art of naming, or of rhetoric, or whatever it be. No, not we; I said that too hastily. For the ancients gave language its existing composite character; and we, if we are to examine all these matters with scientific ability, must take it to pieces as they put it together and see whether the words, both the earliest and the later, are given systematically or not; for if they are strung together at haphazard, it is a poor, unmethodical performance, my dear Hermogenes.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: By Zeus, Socrates, may be it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, do you believe you could take them to pieces in that way? I do not believe I could.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Then I am sure I could not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we give up then? Or shall we do the best we can and try to see if we are able to understand even a little about them, and, just as we said to the gods a while ago that we knew nothing about the truth but were guessing at human opinion about them, so now, before we proceed, shall we say to ourselves that if anyone, whether we or someone else, is to make any analysis of names, he will have to analyze them in the way we have described, and we shall have to study them, as the saying is, with all our might? Do you agree, or not?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Yes, I agree most heartily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It will, I imagine, seem ridiculous that things are made manifest through imitation in letters and syllables; nevertheless it cannot be otherwise. For there is no better theory upon which we can base the truth of the earliest names, unless you think we had better follow the example of the tragic poets, who, when they are in a dilemma, have recourse to the introduction of gods on machines. So we may get out of trouble by saying that the gods gave the earliest names, and therefore they are right. Is that the best theory for us? Or perhaps this one, that we got the earliest names from some foreign folk and the foreigners are more ancient than we are? Or that it is impossible to investigate them because of their antiquity, as is also the case with the foreign words? All these are merely very clever evasions on the part of those who refuse to offer any rational theory of the correctness of the earliest names. And yet if anyone is, no matter why, ignorant of the correctness of the earliest names, he cannot know about that of the later, since they can be explained only by means of the earliest, about which he is ignorant. No, it is clear that anyone who claims to have scientific knowledge of names must be able first of all to explain the earliest names perfectly, or he can be sure that what he says about the later will be nonsense. Or do you disagree?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: No, Socrates, not in the least.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now I think my notions about the earliest names are quite outrageous and ridiculous. I will impart them to you, if you like; if you can find anything better, please try to impart it to me.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: I will do so. Go on, and do not be afraid.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First, then, the letter rho seems to me to be an instrument expressing all motion. We have not as yet said why motion has the name ki/nhsis; but it evidently should be i)/esis, for in old times we did not employ eta, but epsilon. And the beginning of ki/nhsis is from ki/ein, a foreign word equivalent to i)e/nai (go). So we should find that the ancient word corresponding to our modern form would be i)/esis; but now by the employment of the foreign word ki/ein, change of epsilon to eta, and the insertion of nu it has become ki/nhsis, though it ought to be kiei/nesis or ei)=sis. And sta/sis (rest) signifies the negation of motion, but is called sta/sis for euphony. Well, the letter rho, as I was saying, appeared to be a fine instrument expressive of motion to the name-giver who wished to imitate rapidity, and he often applies it to motion. In the first place, in the words r(ei=n (flow) and r(oh/ (current) he imitates their rapidity by this letter, then in tro/mos (trembling) and in tre/xein (run), and also in such words as krou/ein (strike), qrau/ein (break), e)rei/kein (rend), qru/ptein (crush),kermati/zein (crumble), r(umbei=n (whirl), he expresses the action of them all chiefly by means of the letter rho; for he observed, I suppose, that the tongue is least at rest and most agitated in pronouncing this letter, and that is probably the reason why he employed it for these words. Iota again, he employs for everything subtle, which can most readily pass through all things. Therefore he imitates the nature of i)e/nai (go) and i(/esqai (hasten) by means of iota, just as he has imitated all such notions as yuxro/n (cold, shivering), ze/on (seething), sei/esqai (shake), and seismo/s (shock) by means of phi, psi, sigma, and zeta, because those letters are pronounced with much breath. Whenever he imitates that which resembles blowing, the giver of names always appears to use for the most part such letters. And again he appears to have thought that the compression and pressure of the tongue in the pronunciation of delta and tau was naturally fitted to imitate the notion of binding and rest. And perceiving that the tongue has a gliding movement most in the pronunciation of lambda, he made the words lei=a (level), o)lisqa/nain (glide) itself, liparo/n (sleek), kollw=des (glutinous), and the like to conform to it. Where the gliding of the tongue is stopped by the sound of gamma he reproduced the nature of glisxro/n (glutinous), gluku/ (sweet), and gloiw=des (gluey). And again, perceiving that nu is an internal sound, he made the words e)/ndon (inside) and e)nto/s (within), assimilating the meanings to the letters, and alpha again he assigned to greatness, and eta to length, because the letters are large. He needed the sign *o for the expression of go/ggulon (round), and made it the chief element of the word. And in this way the lawgiver appears to apply the other letters, making by letters and syllables a name for each and every thing, and from these names he compounds all the rest by imitation. This, Hermogenes, appears to me to be the theory of the correctness of names, unless, indeed, Cratylus has some other view.

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p: Truly, Socrates, as I said in the beginning, Cratylus often troubles me a good deal; he declares that there is such a thing as correctness of names, but does not say clearly what it is; and so I cannot tell whether he speaks so obscurely about it on any given occasion intentionally or unintentionally. So now, Cratylus, tell me, in the presence of Socrates, do you like what Socrates says about names, or have you a better theory to propose? And if you have, tell us about it; then you will either learn from Socrates or instruct both him and me.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: But, Hermogenes, do you think it is an easy matter to learn or teach any subject so quickly, especially so important an one as this, which appears to me to be one of the most important?

sp.speaker: Hermogenes
sp.p:
No, by Zeus, I do not. But I think Hesiod is right in saying:
If you can only add little to little, it is worth while.Hes. WD 359 So now if you can make even a little progress, do not shirk the trouble, but oblige Socrates—you owe it to him—and me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For that matter, Cratylus, I would not positively affirm any of the things I have said. I merely expressed the opinions which I reached with the help of Hermogenes. So far as I am concerned, you need not hesitate, and if your view is better than mine, I will accept it. And I should not be at all surprised if it were better; for I think you have not only investigated such matters yourself but have been taught about them by others. So if you have any better theory to propound, put me down as one of your pupils in the course on the correctness of names.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p:
Yes, Socrates, I have, as you say, paid attention to these matters, and perhaps I might make you my pupil. However, I am afraid the opposite is the case, and I am impelled to say to you what Achilles says in the “Prayers” to Ajax. He says:
Ajax, descendant of Zeus, son of Telamon, chief of thy people,
All thou hast uttered is good in my sight and pleases my spirit.Hom. Il. 9.644 f And so, Socrates, your oracular utterances seem to me to be much to my mind, whether you are inspired by Euthyphro or some other Muse has dwelt within you all along without our knowing it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
My excellent Cratylus, I myself have been marvelling at my own wisdom all along, and I cannot believe in it. So I think we ought to reexamine my utterances. For the worst of all deceptions is self-deception. How can it help being terrible, when the deceiver is always present and never stirs from the spot? So I think we must turn back repeatedly to what we have said and must try, as the poet says, to look
both forwards and backwards.Hom. Il. 1.343; 3.109 Then let us now see what we have said. Correctness of a name, we say, is the quality of showing the nature of the thing named. Shall we call that a satisfactory statement?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I am perfectly satisfied with it, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Names, then, are given with a view to instruction?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we, then; say that this instruction is an art and has its artisans?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: The lawgivers, as you said in the beginning.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we declare that this art arises in men like the other arts, or not? What I mean is this: Some painters are better, and others worse, are they not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the better produce better works—that is, their paintings—and the others worse works? And likewise some builders build better houses and others worse?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do some lawgivers produce better, and others worse works?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: No; at that point I cease to agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you do not think that some laws are better, and some worse?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you do not, it appears, think that one name is better, and another worse?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then all names are correct?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: All that are really names.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How about the name of our friend Hermogenes, which was mentioned a while ago? Shall we say that it is not his name at all, unless he belongs to the race of Hermes, or that it is his name, but is incorrect?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think, Socrates, that it is not his name at all; it appears to be his, but is really the name of some one else who possesses the nature that makes the name clear.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when anyone says that our friend is Hermogenes, is he not even speaking falsely? For perhaps it is not even possible to say that he is Hermogenes, if he is not.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you mean to say that it is impossible to speak falsehood at all? For there are, my dear Cratylus, many who do so, and who have done so in the past.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Why, Socrates, how could anyone who says that which he says, say that which is not? Is not falsehood saying that which is not?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Your reasoning is too clever for me at my age, my friend. However, tell me this: Do you think it is possible to speak falsehood, but not to say it?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Neither to speak nor to say it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor utter it or use it as a form of address? For instance, if some one should meet you in hospitable fashion, should grasp your hand and say, “Well met, my friend from Athens, son of Smicrion, Hermogenes,” would he be saying or speaking or uttering or addressing these words not to you, but to Hermogenes—or to nobody?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think, Socrates, the man would be producing sounds without sense.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Even that reply is welcome; for I can ask whether the words he produced would be true, or false, or partly true and partly false. Even that would suffice.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I should say that the man in such a case was merely making a noise, going through purposeless motions, as if he were beating a bronze pot.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us see, Cratylus, if we cannot come to terms somehow. You would agree, would you not, that the name is one thing and the thing of which it is the name is another?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, I should.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you agree that the name is an imitation of the thing named?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Most assuredly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you agree that paintings also are imitations, though in a different way, of things?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then—for perhaps I do not understand, and you may be right—can both of these imitations, the paintings and the names, be assigned and applied to the things which they imitate, or not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: They can.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First, then, consider this question: Can we assign the likeness of the man to the man and that of the woman to the woman, and so forth?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can we conversely attribute that of the man to the woman, and the woman's to the man?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is also possible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are these assignments both correct, or only the former?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: The former.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The assignment, in short, which attributes to each that which belongs to it and is like it.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is my view.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: To put an end to contentious argument between you and me, since we are friends, let me state my position. I call that kind of assignment in the case of both imitations paintings and names—correct, and in the case of names not only correct, but true; and the other kind, which gives and applies the unlike imitation, I call incorrect and, in the case of names, false.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: But it may be, Socrates, that this incorrect assignment is possible in the case of paintings, and not in the case of names, which must be always correctly assigned.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What do you mean? What difference is there between the two? Can I not step up to a man and say to him, “This is your portrait,” and show him perhaps his own likeness or, perhaps, that of a woman? And by “show” I mean bring before the sense of sight.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, can I not step up to the same man again and say, “This is your name”? A name is an imitation, just as a picture is. Very well; can I not say to him, “This is your name,” and then bring before his sense of hearing perhaps the imitation of himself, saying that it is a man, or perhaps the imitation of the female of the human species, saying that it is a woman? Do you not believe that this is possible and sometimes happens?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I am willing to concede it, Socrates, and grant that you are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is a good thing for you to do, my friend, if I am right; for now we need no longer argue about the matter. If, then, some such assignment of names takes place, we will call one kind speaking truth, and the other speaking falsehood. But if this is accepted, and if it is possible to assign names incorrectly and to give to objects not the names that befit them, but sometimes those that are unfitting, it would be possible to treat verbs in the same way. And if verbs and nouns can be assigned in this way, the same must be true of sentences; for sentences are, I conceive, a combination of verbs and nouns. What do you say to that, Cratylus?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I agree; I think you are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If, then, we compare the earliest words to sketches, it is possible in them, as in pictures, to reproduce all the colors and shapes, or not all; some may be wanting, and some may be added, and they may be too many or too large. Is not that true?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then he who reproduces all, produces good sketches and pictures, and he who adds or takes away produces also sketches and pictures, but bad ones?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how about him who imitates the nature of things by means of letters and syllables? By the same principle, if he gives all that is appropriate, the image—that is to say, the name—will be good, and if he sometimes omits a little, it will be an image, but not a good one; and therefore some names are well and others badly made. Is that not true?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps, then, one artisan of names will be good, and another bad?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The name of such an artisan was lawgiver?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps, then, by Zeus, as is the case in the other arts, one lawgiver may be good and another bad, if we accept our previous conclusions.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is true. But you see, Socrates, when by the science of grammar we assign these letters—alpha, beta, and the rest—to names, if we take away or add or transpose any letter, it is not true that the name is written, but written incorrectly; it is not written at all, but immediately becomes a different word, if any such thing happens to it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps we are not considering the matter in the right way.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It may be that what you say would be true of those things which must necessarily consist of a certain number or cease to exist at all, as ten, for instance, or any number you like, if you add or subtract anything is immediately another number; but this is not the kind of correctness which applies to quality or to images in general; on the contrary, the image must not by any means reproduce all the qualities of that which it imitates, if it is to be an image. See if I am not right. Would there be two things, Cratylus and the image of Cratylus, if some god should not merely imitate your color and form, as painters do, but should also make all the inner parts like yours, should reproduce the same flexibility and warmth, should put into them motion, life, and intellect, such as exist in you, and in short, should place beside you a duplicate of all your qualities? Would there be in such an event Cratylus and an image of Cratylus, or two Cratyluses?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I should say, Socrates, two Cratyluses.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then don't you see, my friend, that we must look for some other principle of correctness in images and in names, of which we were speaking, and must not insist that they are no longer images if anything be wanting or be added? Do you not perceive how far images are from possessing the same qualities as the originals which they imitate?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Surely, Cratylus, the effect produced by the names upon the things of which they are the names would be ridiculous, if they were to be entirely like them in every respect. For everything would be duplicated, and no one could tell in any case which was the real thing and which the name.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Quite true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, I remember.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Very well, then. So long as this intrinsic quality is present, even though the name have not all the proper letters, the thing will still be named; well, when it has all the proper letters; badly, when it has only a few of them. Let us, then, grant this, my friend, or we shall get into trouble, like the belated night wanderers in the road at Aegina,This seems to refer to some story unknown to us. and in very truth we shall be found to have arrived too late; otherwise you must look for some other principle of correctness in names, and must not admit that a name is the representation of a thing in syllables and letters. For if you maintain both positions, you cannot help contradicting yourself.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Well, Socrates, I think what you say is reasonable, and I accept it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then since we are agreed about this, let us consider the next point. If a name, we say, is to be a good one, it must have the proper letters?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the proper letters are those which are like the things named?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is, then, the method by which wellgiven names are given. But if any name is not well given, the greater part of it may perhaps, if it is to be an image at all, be made up of proper and like letters, but it may contain some inappropriate element, and is on that account not good or well made. Is that our view?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I suppose, Socrates, there is no use in keeping up my contention; but I am not satisfied that it can be a name and not be well given.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are you not satisfied that the name is the representation of a thing?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you not think it is true that some names are composed of earlier ones and others are primary?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if the primary names are to be representations of any things, can you suggest any better way of making them representations than by making them as much as possible like the things which they are to represent? Or do you prefer the theory advanced by Hermogenes and many others, who claim that names are conventional and represent things to those who established the convention and knew the things beforehand, and that convention is the sole principle of correctness in names, and it makes no difference whether we accept the existing convention or adopt an opposite one according to which small would be called great and great small? Which of these two theories do you prefer?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Representing by likeness the thing represented is absolutely and entirely superior to representation by chance signs.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are right. Then if the name is like the thing, the letters of which the primary names are to be formed must be by their very nature like the things, must they not? Let me explain. Could a painting, to revert to our previous comparison, ever be made like any real thing, if there were no pigments out of which the painting is composed, which were by their nature like the objects which the painter's art imitates? Is not that impossible?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In the same way, names can never be like anything unless those elements of which the names are composed exist in the first place and possess some kind of likeness to the things which the names imitate; and the elements of which they are composed are the letters, are they not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then I must now ask you to consider with me the subject which Hermogenes and I discussed a while ago. Do you think I am right in saying that rho is expressive of speed, motion, and hardness, or not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And lambda is like smoothness, softness, and the other qualities we mentioned?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You know, of course, that we call the same thing sklhro/ths (hardness) which the Eretrians call sklhro/thr?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Have rho and sigma both a likeness to the same thing, and does the final rho mean to them just what the sigma means to us, or is there to one of us no meaning?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: They mean the same to both.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In so far as rho and sigma are alike, or in so far as they are not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: In so far as they are alike.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are they alike in all respects?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes; at least for the purpose of expressing motion equally.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But how about the lambda in sklhro/ths? Does it not express the opposite of hardness?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Well, perhaps it has no right to be there, Socrates; it may be like the cases that came up in your talk with Hermogenes, when you removed or inserted letters where that was necessary. I think you did right; and in this case perhaps we ought to put a rho in place of the lambda.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Excellent. However, do we not understand one another when anyone says sklhro/n, using the present pronunciation, and do you not now know what I mean?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, but that is by custom, my friend.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In saying “custom” do you think you are saying anything different from convention? Do you not mean by “convention” that when I speak I have a definite meaning and you recognize that I have that meaning? Is not that what you mean?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if you recognize my meaning when I speak, that is an indication given to you by me.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The indication comes from something which is unlike my meaning when I speak, if in your example sklhro/ths the lambda is unlike hardness; and if this is true, did you not make a convention with yourself, since both like and unlike letters, by the influence of custom and convention, produce indication? And even if custom is entirely distinct from convention, we should henceforth be obliged to say that custom, not likeness, is the principle of indication, since custom, it appears, indicates both by the like and by the unlike. And since we grant this, Cratylus—for I take it that your silence gives consent—both convention and custom must contribute something towards the indication of our meaning when we speak. For, my friend, if you will just turn your attention to numbers, where do you think you can possibly get names to apply to each individual number on the principle of likeness, unless you allow agreement and convention on your part to control the correctness of names? I myself prefer the theory that names are, so far as is possible, like the things named; but really this attractive force of likeness is, as Hermogenes says, a poor thing, and we are compelled to employ in addition this commonplace expedient, convention, to establish the correctness of names. Probably language would be, within the bounds of possibility, most excellent when all its terms, or as many as possible, were based on likeness, that is to say, were appropriate, and most deficient under opposite conditions. But now answer the next question. What is the function of names, and what good do they accomplish?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think, Socrates, their function is to instruct, and this is the simple truth, that he who knows the names knows also the things named.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I suppose, Cratylus, you mean that when anyone knows the nature of the name—and its nature is that of the thing—he will know the thing also, since it is like the name, and the science of all things which are like each other is one and the same. It is, I fancy, on this ground that you say whoever knows names will know things also.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: You are perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now let us see what this manner of giving instruction is, to which you refer, and whether there is another method, but inferior to this, or there is no other at all. What do you think?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think there is no other at all; this is both the best and the only method.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you think this is also the method of discovering realities, and that he who has discovered the names has discovered also the things named; or do you think inquiry and discovery demand another method, and this belongs to instruction?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I most certainly think inquiry and discovery follow this same method and in the same way.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us consider the matter, Cratylus. Do you not see that he who in his inquiry after things follows names and examines into the meaning of each one runs great risks of being deceived?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Clearly he who first gave names, gave such names as agreed with his conception of the nature of things. That is our view, is it not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if his conception was incorrect, and he gave the names according to his conception, what do you suppose will happen to us who follow him? Can we help being deceived?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: But, Socrates, surely that is not the case. He who gave the names must necessarily have known; otherwise, as I have been saying all along, they would not be names at all. And there is a decisive proof that the name-giver did not miss the truth, one which you must accept; for otherwise his names would not be so universally consistent. Have you not yourself noticed in speaking that all names were formed by the same method and with the same end in view?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But that, Cratylus, is no counter argument. For if the giver of names erred in the beginning and thenceforth forced all other names into agreement with his own initial error, there is nothing strange about that. It is just so sometimes in geometrical diagrams; the initial error is small and unnoticed, but all the numerous deductions are wrong, though consistent. Every one must therefore give great care and great attention to the beginning of any undertaking, to see whether his foundation is right or not. If that has been considered with proper care, everything else will follow. However, I should be surprised if names are really consistent. Let us review our previous discussion. Names, we said, indicate nature to us, assuming that all things are in motion and flux. Do you not think they do so?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, and they indicate it correctly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us first take up again the word e)pisth/mh (knowledge) and see how ambiguous it is, seeming to indicate that it makes our soul stand still (i(/sthsin) at things, rather than that it is carried round with them, so it is better to speak the beginning of it as we now do than to insert the epsilon and say e)pei+sth/m; we should insert an iota rather than an epsilon. Then take be/baion (firm), which expresses position and rest, not motion. And i(stori/a (inquiry) means much the same, that it stops (i(/sthsin) the flow. And pisto/n (faithful) most certainly means that which stops (i(sto/n) motion. Then again, anyone can see that mnh/mh (memory) expresses rest (monh/) in the soul, not motion. On the other hand, a(marti/a (error) and cumfora/ (misfortune), if you consider merely the form of the names, will appear to be the same as su/nesis (intellect) and e)pisth/mh and all the other names of good significance. Moreover, a)maqi/a (ignorance) and a)kolasi/a (unrestraint) also appear to be like them; for the former, a)maqi/a, seems to be tou= a(/ma qew=| i)o/ntos porei/a (the progress of one who goes with God), and a)kolasi/a seems to be exactly a)kolouqi/a toi=s pra/gmasin (movement in company with things). And so names which we believe have the very worst meanings appear to be very like those which have the best. And I think we could, if we took pains, find many other words which would lead us to reverse our judgement and believe that the giver of names meant that things were not in progress or in motion, but were at rest.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: But, Socrates, you see that most of the names indicate motion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What of that, Cratylus? Are we to count names like votes, and shall correctness rest with the majority? Are those to be the true names which are found to have that one of the two meanings which is expressed by the greater number?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is not reasonable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, not in the least, my friend. Now let us drop this and return to the point at which we digressed. A little while ago, you may remember, you said he who gave names must have known the things to which he gave them. Do you still hold that opinion, or not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you say that he who gave the first names also knew the things which he named?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes, he knew them.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But from what names had he learned or discovered the things, if the first names had not yet been given, and if we declare that it is impossible to learn or discover things except by learning or ourselves discovering the names?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think there is something in what you say, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How can we assert that they gave names or were lawgivers with knowledge, before any name whatsoever had been given, and before they knew any names, if things cannot be learned except through their names?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think the truest theory of the matter, Socrates, is that the power which gave the first names to things is more than human, and therefore the names must necessarily be correct.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, in your opinion, he who gave the names, though he was a spirit or a god, would have given names which made him contradict himself? Or do you think there is no sense in what we were saying just now?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: But, Socrates, those that make up one of the two classes are not really names.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Which of the two, my excellent friend; the class of those which point towards rest or of those that point towards motion? We agreed just now that the matter is not to be determined by mere numbers.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: No; that would not be right, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then since the names are in conflict, and some of them claim that they are like the truth, and others that they are, how can we decide, and upon what shall we base our decision? Certainly not upon other names differing from these, for there are none. No, it is plain that we must look for something else, not names, which shall show us which of these two kinds are the true names, which of them, that is to say, show the truth of things.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is my opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if that is true, Cratylus, it seems that things may be learned without names.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What other way is left by which you could expect to know them? What other than the natural and the straightest way, through each other, if they are akin, and through themselves? For that which is other and different from them would signify not them, but something other and different.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think that is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Stop for Heaven's sake! Did we not more than once agree that names which are rightly given are like the things named and are images of them?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if it be really true that things can be learned either through names or through themselves which would be the better and surer way of learning? To learn from the image whether it is itself a good imitation and also to learn the truth which it imitates, or to learn from the truth both the truth itself and whether the image is properly made?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think it is certainly better to learn from the truth.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How realities are to be learned or discovered is perhaps too great a question for you or me to determine; but it is worth while to have reached even this conclusion, that they are to be learned and sought for, not from names but much better through themselves than through names.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is clear, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us examine one further point to avoid being deceived by the fact that most of these names tend in the same direction. Suppose it should prove that although those who gave the names gave them in the belief that all things are in motion and flux—I myself think they did have that belief— still in reality that is not the case, and the namegivers themselves, having fallen into a kind of vortex, are whirled about, dragging us along with them. Consider, my worthy Cratylus, a question about which I often dream. Shall we assert that there is any absolute beauty, or good, or any other absolute existence, or not?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I think there is, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us consider the absolute, not whether a particular face, or something of that sort, is beautiful, or whether all these things are in flux. Is not, in our opinion, absolute beauty always such as it is?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is inevitable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Can we, then, if it is always passing away, correctly say that it is this, then that it is that, or must it inevitably, in the very instant while we are speaking, become something else and pass away and no longer be what it is?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: That is inevitable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How, then, can that which is never in the same state be anything? For if it is ever in the same state, then obviously at that time it is not changing; and if it is always in the same state and is always the same, how can it ever change or move without relinquishing its own form?

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: It cannot do so at all.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, nor can it be known by anyone. For at the moment when he who seeks to know it approaches, it becomes something else and different, so that its nature and state can no longer be known; and surely there is no knowledge which knows that which is in no state.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: It is as you say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But we cannot even say that there is any knowledge, if all things are changing and nothing remains fixed; for if knowledge itself does not change and cease to be knowledge, then knowledge would remain, and there would be knowledge; but if the very essence of knowledge changes, at the moment of the change to another essence of knowledge there would be no knowledge, and if it is always changing, there will always be no knowledge, and by this reasoning there will be neither anyone to know nor anything to be known. But if there is always that which knows and that which is known—if the beautiful, the good, and all the other verities exist—I do not see how there is any likeness between these conditions of which I am now speaking and flux or motion. Now whether this is the nature of things, or the doctrine of Heracleitus and many others is true, is another question; but surely no man of sense can put himself and his soul under the control of names, and trust in names and their makers to the point of affirming that he knows anything; nor will he condemn himself and all things and say that there is no health in them, but that all things are flowing like leaky pots, or believe that all things are just like people afflicted with catarrh, flowing and running all the time. Perhaps, Cratylus, this theory is true, but perhaps it is not. Therefore you must consider courageously and thoroughly and not accept anything carelessly—for you are still young and in your prime; then, if after investigation you find the truth, impart it to me.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: I will do so. However, I assure you, Socrates, that I have already considered the matter, and after toilsome consideration I think the doctrine of Heracleitus is much more likely to be true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Some other time, then, my friend, you will teach me, when you come back; but now go into the country as you have made ready to do; and Hermogenes here will go with you a bit.

sp.speaker: Cratylus
sp.p: Very well, Socrates, and I hope you also will continue to think of these matters.
